How to become a member

Any person who has attained 18 years age can be a member of KSSP.  Memebrship form will be obtained from Unit Secretaris of the concerned locality. The normal memebrship time is November - January. The membership has to be renewed every year. Fee for new membership is Rs 10/- and for rnewal is Rs11/-. The memebrship application will be scrutinised and accepted by the Zonal committee of the concerned locality. General Querries on memebrship pl contact :

Treasurer                  - Narayanan P K    or   9446530271

2017 Application for Membership - new.docx.pdf


Membership of SSSF is open to anyone with a Swedish or Scandinavian connection that has interest in helping the SSSF further its objective "To own, maintain and operate and preserve the Swedish American Hall at 2174 Market Street in San Francisco. To facilitate Scandinavian cultural events at the Swedish American Hall and in the Bay Area."

Prospective members have to be proposed by two current members and after membership committee recommendation taken up as members after approval by the Board of Directors.

There is no initiation or annual membership fee, but members are expected to contribute to the society's activities and to attend the annual meeting and other events.


To apply for membership, print out and fill out the form to the left. Scan it and e-mail it to

Events & Sponsorships





Bloomington-Normal Young Professionals provides many opportunities throughout the year for our membership to get involved with. We have a set calendar but as the year moves forward we do have changes, updates, and additions. All information about location, speaker, and topic for our membership meetings is provided about a month prior in our Weekly Wednesday Updates (WWU).  


Updates to our calendar with added socials or spontaneous events are sent out to our membership through the WWU’s as well. All members are encouraged to read those emails for any changes to our Membership Calendar. If you have questions or concerns, please contact the 2021 President Tessa Mizell.



BNYP Sponsorships

Our monthly BNYP Meetings happen because of the amazing sponsors we have that host and provide a raffle for meetings. If you are interested in hosting BNYP or providing a raffle item, please click below to find out more information and dates that are available.

New Website Coming Soon


Scouting's Journey to Excellence, the new performance standard in the BSA, encourages your unit to go for the gold this year in service to our community.  As your unit racks up the service hours, track them for your unit's Journey to Excellence measure by clicking hereExternal Link.  For information for first time users, click hereExternal Link.

For more information abour Journey to Excellence in general, click hereExternal Link.

Before logging on, you will need your unit ID number.  This is the same number you use for the online advancement system.  If you do not know this number, please contact the Scout Achievement Center at 513.577.7700.

These hours will be uswed as part of a larger program designed to recognize high performing units and help all of us improve the quality of Scouting programs delivered to youth.  For over 100 years, the Boy Scouts of America has enthusiastically given service to our community.  Be a part of this noble tradition and go for the service gold this year!

Project Volunteers
Help on large bulk mailings and volume copying on a quarterly basis or on special occasions. Time commitment: Flexible. Computer skills desired, but not necessary.

Service Volunteers
Help on hospital projects, for example:

  • Birthdays
  • Holiday Decorating
  • Service Events: Blood Drive, Pediatric Picnic, Pajama Party, or special occasions. (Special Events are on a seasonal basis.)

Individuals needed to chair or participate in event committees. Can participate in one event or more or take on specific projects. For example:

  • Solicitation of Silent Auction items
  • Solicitation of Sponsors
  • Advertising/Publicity
  • Event Preparation: Invitations, Mailers, Printing, Computer Entry, Office Work, etc.
  • Raffle Ticket Sales
  • Volunteers to Staff the Events
  • Event Set-up and Clean-up

We welcome volunteers of all ages. To help, please call the DGF at: (818) 249-1105 or email igeestman@4desi.org

Membership in the Wellesley Club is limited to 300 members and a Wait List of 100. Members may invite guests to the meetings.

Click here to view Membership and Wait List as of September 30, 2013.  For a copy of the Club’s Constitution and By-Laws, click here.

The process for membership in the Wellesley Club is by nomination from an existing Wellesley Club member. To be nominated for membership, a candidate must fill out the attached Proposal for Membership form, have it signed by your member sponsor and two directors. When completed, the form must be returned to the Club Secretary.  At the next appropriate Board of Directors meeting, the nomination will be voted upon by the Board of Directors for acceptance to the Wait List and then formally presented to the club membership in the next meeting invitation.

Dues: Annual dues are paid prior to the first meeting in the Fall.

2017-2018 Dues may now be paid online by CLICKING HERE.

The 2017-2018 Annual Dues are as follows:

  • Members - $195.00, which includes four dinner meetings
  • Wait List – $195.00, which includes four dinner meetings
  • Non-resident members – $25 dues, plus $65 for any dinner meetings attended
  • Guests of members - $65 paid at time of reservation

For more information, email:

Contact Us

Need a product reviewed or want to get in contact with us?

This is where you can get that done.

If you can’t find what you’re looking for or  if you simply have any questions, you can always reach us by using the contact form below.

You will usually get a response within 24 hours, but if for some odd reason I don’t get back to you within that time, you can come right back and submit another message.

Now if we still don’t respond to you, wait longer.

Just kidding!

But if I really don’t respond to you after the 2nd time, go right ahead and leave me some bad feedback on my about me page and I will do some pushups just for missing your message.

I look forward to hearing from you!

Contact us

Thank you very much for visiting Moms Uniting Moms! We are very glad to have you here in our website! You should contact us in the soonest possible time so that we can help you out in all the things that you need to be done. We will be there to answer calls and questions for you!

How do I become a volunteer?

Volunteers perform a range of roles for the Council, covering a vast range of areas of interest and expertise. Opportunities exist for volunteers to contribute many services across the Council, including:

Aged and Disability Services

 Youth Programs

 Arts and Cultural Programs


Parks and Outdoors

 Community Events

  • Benalla Festival and Australia Day events

Specialist Committees

  • Specialist committees such as the Audit Committee

If you wish to volunteer within the community at a different organisation, you may find their contact details on Who? What? Where? Benalla Community Directory.

Becoming a volunteer

Register you interest in volunteering with the Council by completing a Volunteer Application Form. You can send this by email back to, or you can deliver it or send it to the Customer Service Centre.

Fill in an online Volunteer Application Form or download a hardcopy Volunteer Application Form(DOC, 311KB)

Download the Volunteer Policy(PDF, 200KB)

It is a regulatory requirement that all volunteers for the Council undergo an induction process. This is important for Occupational Health and Safety reasons. Induction is an easy online process, and once you are inducted as a volunteer for one Council activity, this applies across all voluntary positions. 

Some volunteering roles require a Police Check and Working With Children’s Check. Costs associated with these checks are covered by the Council.

For all other queries including media, donations & official business, Email is the preferred method of contact - we tend to respond within a few hours to most messages.

Chapter News in Air Force Magazine

Chapter News in Air Force Magazine

To: AFA Field Leaders
From: Adam J. Hebert, Editor in Chief
Date: May 2016

Members frequently ask how to get news of a chapter event into Air Force Magazine. Here are the basics:

The “Chapter News" within Air Force Magazine, covers chapter activities.

The magazine point of contact for chapter news is Assistant Managing Editor Chequita Wood. Her email address is Her mailing address is Air Force Magazine, 1501 Lee Highway, Arlington VA 22209-1190.

Give us basic, factual information about your event. Please don’t expend a great deal of effort on writing. Just provide the basics: Who? What? Where? When? Why? How? We’ll contact you for more details.

We’re looking for a specific and direct link to the AFA chapter, so clearly stating that connection will help us greatly.

If you’re sending a photo of children, please let their parents know that the photo might appear in print or on the Web.

Email photos at the highest resolution possible, one at a time.

We prefer unposed, candid photos showing people in action--not posing for the camera.

Family Services


Tribal Operations & Family Services

Tribal Enrollment (Membership)

Criteria for Membership: By the Constitution Ratified Sept. 29, 1999:


SECTION 1. Membership
The following persons shall be eligible for membership in the Wyandotte Nation: PROVIDED, That such persons are United States citizens and not enrolled members of any other federally recognized tribe, nation, band, group or, community.  (a) All persons whose names appear on the official Census Roll of the Nation as of January 1, 1937;  (b) All issue by blood of a Wyandotte Nation tribal member listed in Section I(a), of this Article; and  (c) The degree of blood quantum of an individual proven to possess Wyandotte blood will not be a factor in determining Wyandotte membership.

SECTION 2. Membership by Council Vote
A person of Wyandotte Nation ancestry who does not meet the requirements of Section 1 of this Article may be accepted for membership by a majority vote of the Nation Council.

SECTION 3. Voluntarily Withdrawing Membership
Any adult member voluntarily withdrawing his or her membership from the Wyandotte Nation does so forever. For purposes of this Section, voluntarily withdrawing membership shall include persons who lose their United States citizenship or who enroll in any other federally recognized tribe, nation, band, group or community after becoming a member of the Nation.

SECTION 4. Rules Governing Membership
The Board of Directors will enact rules governing voluntary withdrawal of membership, termination of membership, the membership application process, provisions for appeal of denial of membership and adoptions.

SECTION 5. Council Decision on Membership
The Board of Directors shall provide in the rules governing membership that the Nation’s Council shall make final decision on the Nation’s membership. The decision of the Nation’s Council shall be final. There shall be no appeals.


Membership Application Process:
New members are added one time a year during the Wyandotte Nation Annual Meeting.  Completed applications must be received in the Enrollment office by August 15, 2016 in order to be considered for enrollment at the 2015 Annual Meeting.

1. Log into the Members Only area to download an application or contact the Wyandotte Nation Family Services Department.
2. The membership application must be completed and returned to this office with an ORIGINAL State Certified Birth Certificate. For applicants who cannot trace his/her ancestry to the 1937 base roll, proof of ancestry lies with the prospective enrollee. All membership applicants are subject to review by the Enrollment Committee.

Membership Record Updates:

1. To report a name change: Send a copy of your marriage license, divorce decree or a court order changing name.
2. To report an address change: Submit your request in written form, via postal service, email or fax statement by tribal member.
3. To report a death: Acceptable documents: death certificates, obituary or memorials.
4. Click here for a replacement citizenship card application.

Certificate of Degree of Indian Blood card:

What is a CDIB card? A Certificate of Degree of Indian Blood certified that an individual possesses a specific degree of Indian blood of a federally recognized Indian Tribe. There are some programs and services based upon your status as an American Indian, which require you to furnish this card before services are rendered. A CDIB card does Not establish membership in a federally recognized Indian Tribe, and it does not prevent an Indian Tribe from making a separate and independent determination of blood degree for tribal purposes. Prior to 1989 the Bureau of Indian Affairs issued these cards to Wyandotte Indians. After 1989, the Wyandotte Nation issued Tribal-issued CDIB cards.

To apply for a CDIB card:

1. Click here to download an application or contact the Wyandotte Nation Family Services Department. Submit completed application along with all Birth Certificates tracing an ancestor to the 1937 base roll. The enrollment department may have some documents. If additional information is required you will be notified.
2. Replacement CDIB cards may be issued upon request.


PLEASE NOTE: Any tribal citizen who has an outstanding balance of more than 60 days due to any Wyandotte Nation department/program will not be eligible for any tribally funded services from the Family Services Department.  Those who have outstanding balances will receive a letter from the Family Services Director with details of their account(s) and will be given information about repayment options.

Senior Energy Assistance: Winter: effective October 1, 2016 through Feb. 28, 2017, senior citizens ages 55+ that reside within the states of Oklahoma, Missouri, Arkansas and Kansas are eligible to apply for $100.00 utility assistance.  Summer: effective July 1, 2017 to Sept. 30, 2017.  Applications may be requested by mail, or at the tribal headquarters or by clicking this link 2018 Senior energy app


Child Passenger Safety Seats:  The child passenger safety seats are currently available at the tribal headquarters from newborn-booster and must be picked up..  Safety first, buckle in. Car Seat Application

Promoting Safe & Stable Families:  The “PSSF” program provides family preservation and support services designed to prevent the breakup of our Indian Families.  This program may be able to provide at risk families with emergency assistance, need based social services, outside referrals, or other tribal programs to ensure the health, well-being and safety of your family.

Indian Child Welfare:  The 1978 Indian Child Welfare Act was designed to protect the Indian Family from unwarranted interference by the Anglo culture.  When a child is involuntarily removed from his/her home, it is the intent of the “Act” to place a child with an immediate family member, an extended family member or a member of the child’s tribe/or other Indian Families.  If your family is involved in a State Court proceeding, the Tribe may be able to assist your family during this difficult process.

Children’s Christmas Party:  This year’s annual Christmas Party is scheduled for December 9, 2017, from 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. at the Bearskin Healthcare and Wellness Center gymnasium.  We hope you will note your calendar and plan to attend.  If you’ve never been, your child is missing a wonderful morning with Santa, toys and sweet things to eat.

SUMMER LIHEAP-(Low Income Home Energy Program) Contingent upon Federal funding. Income guidelines apply.  Tribal citizens who believe they are eligible for this program please contact Family Services staff after July 1, 2017 for an application.

New Enrollee Benefit:  Enroll your child before his/her first birthday and you will receive a $100.00 gift card and a baby blanket with the tribal logo.  An enrollment application and birth certificate are required.  This is a nationwide program.

Burial Assistance:  This Nationwide program allows $1,500.00 payment toward the burial expenses of a tribal citizen.  An application, death certificate and itemized funeral bill are required.  Burial Assistance Guidelines

School Supply Program:  The School Supply program will be available beginning July 1st and for the first time will be available to all enrolled tribal citizens pre-K through grade 12 regardless of where they live!  Applications are available on the homepage of this website, in the office or can be mailed to you beginning July 1st.  Walmart gift cards will still be available to residents of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Kansas and Missouri.  Tribal citizens who reside outside of the 4 states will be required to use the reimbursement program.  For those who have utilized the program in the past please note the following change, original applications and receipts will be required.  We will no longer accept applications and receipts via fax or email. 

The program is available from July 1st – September 30th.  Applications MUST be received or postmarked by September 30th to be eligible AND the receipts MUST also be dated between July 1st and September 30th.  NO EXCEPTIONS.  There will be additional instructions along with the applications, but if you have any questions regarding eligible expenditures, how to complete the form, etc. please feel free to contact the Family Services Department at 918-678-6329 or 918-678-6319.

Winter School Clothing: Effective November 1, 2017 through February 28, 2018, a $100.00 clothing allowance is provided to tribal members age pre-K through the 12th grade.  No income guidelines apply:  Must reside in the states of Oklahoma, Missouri, Arkansas and Kansas.  Tribal citizens can either a winter clothing reimbursement2018 winter clothing reimburse app or for a2018 winter clothing gift card app.  Please complete the appropriate form and submit to Family Services staff.

Elders Assistance: No income guidelines apply: Benefit $250.00.  Begins October 1, 2016 – September 30, 2017.  This benefit is for senior citizens 55+ age:  Must reside in the states of Oklahoma, Missouri, Arkansas and Kansas to qualify for this assistance. 2018 Elders Assistance App

Children’s Extracurricular Activities: No income guidelines apply: Four states residents are eligible (Oklahoma, Missouri, Arkansas and Kansas): $100.00 per school age child (pre-K through grade 12)effective for the 2016-2017 school year.  Receipts MUST be dated within the fiscal year of October 1, 2016-September 30, 2017. 2018 Extracurricular Activities App

Junior/Senior Assistance: No income guidelines apply: Four state residency required (Oklahoma, Missouri, Arkansas and Kansas): $250 per school/fiscal year (October 1-September 30). 2018 Junior Senior application

Supplemental Health Benefit (Benny card):  Family Services staff can assist with basic questions regarding this program, but may, at times, refer tribal citizens to CoreSource (the company who manages this program for the Wyandotte Nation). They can be reached directl... (truncated)

Community Support Services

The Indigenous Community Links (ICL) Service in Broken Hill is for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and their families.

ICL staff can link you to information and services that can help you.

The ICL, at Maari Ma's regional office, 2 Oxide St, Broken Hill is a welcoming place where you and your family can go to find information and services in your area that meet your needs.

Come in and find out how we can help you link to a range of services.

  • Have a chat.
  • Get advice.
  • Make an appointment.
  • Get a referral.
  • Find out what to expect from services.
  • Use the internet for free.

If you need help, support, advice or assistance, drop in and talk to our friendly staff.

Social and Community Programs

Ongoing Programs

WINGS Drop-In Centre / Safe Aboriginal Youth

Building confidence in kids and encouraging them to have a go

The WINGS Drop-in Centre provides youth development activities in Wilcannia including school holiday programs, after school programs, support for the Far West Academy of Sport including the junior rugby league program and community cultural activities.

Contact Tania Lawson on 08 8097 5368

Attendance to the WINGS program has increased significantly with the addition of new staff. Transport is available to and from the service by WINGS staff.

Other Community Programs

Little Kids & Books

In Menindee, Wilcannia and Broken Hill, families can join in with their little kids - sharing a book (and taking it home), morning tea and songs.

Broken Hill: Part of Playgroup every Friday during school terms 10:30am - 1:00pm at the Maari Ma Child and Family building: 428 Argent Street, Broken Hill.

Menindee: Every fortnight at Menindee Children’s centre.

Please contact Dimity Kelly at the Menindee Health Service on 8091 4209 for more information. 

Wilcannia: Part of the Little Darlings Preschool.

Contact Valerie Bugmy on 08 8091 5368 for more information. 

Maari Ma Healthy Start Playgroup

Playgroup is for little kids (0 – 5 years) to talk, sing, read and play. A space is provided for parents to meet with other parents, for children to play and learn and to make friends. As part of the Little Kids and Books program, children receive a new book each fortnight.

PLAYGROUP runs every Friday during school terms 10:30am – 1:00pm

Broken Hill: Playgroup is at the Maari Ma Child and Family building: 428 Argent Street, Broken Hill.

Please contact Michelle Parker (Early Years Project Leader) on 8082 9888 if you are interested in attending or need transport.

What is a Senior Resource Finder?

Dakota Community Centre is home to the Senior Resource Finder for the St.Boniface and St. Vital area. The Senior Resource Finder (SRF) helps link older adults 55+ to community supports, programs, and services within their community. Some of the services provided are E.R.I.K. (Emergency Response Information Kit), transportation referrals, and networking and community outreach.

Megan Moore, SRF and Program Coordinator for Older Adults & Volunteers at Dakota Community Centre partners with various health, social services, and community sectors to assist with promoting health and well-being of older adults in this area.

Are you a senior or know a senior who may benefit from her support services?

Contact Megan today by phone 204-254-1010 ext. 217 or by e-mail at MeganM@Dakotacc.com

For Support Services in french please contact the Conseil Des Francophones 55+
​123-400 Rue Des Meurons
Winnipeg, MB R2H 3H3
